problem_description: Level 2 Logic - Identifying Logical Fallacies (Affirming the Consequent)
hypothesis_templates: ((p implies q) and q) implies p

training_data.comment: The 'raining' example. P=is_raining, Q=ground_is_wet. If P is false (sprinkler) but Q is true, the conclusion P is false. The fallacy is invalid.
Another case. P=True, Q=True. In this specific case, the statement happens to evaluate to True, but it's not a universal law.
